list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f$ and $g$ be functions such that $g(x) = 3f(x-2)+1$, for
$x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ after the following
transformations:

$$
\begin{aligned}&\text{a vertical stretch by a factor of $k$, followed by} \\&\text{a horizontal translation of $a$ units, followed by} \\&\text{a vertical translation of $b$ units}. \\\end{aligned}
$$


- Write down the value of:
- $k$;
- $a$;
- $b$. [3]



Let $h(x) = -2g(x)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The point P$(3,4)$ on the graph of $g$ is mapped to point Q on the graph
of $h$.

- Find the coordinates of Q.[3]
list.markScheme:
- 
- $\answer{k = 3}$
- $\answer{a = 2}$
- $\answer{b = 1}$

- The graph of $h$ is obtained from the graph of $g$ using two
transformations.Their geometric descriptions are:
$$
\begin{aligned}\text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $2$;} \\[6pt]\text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{reflection in the $x$-axis.}\end{aligned}
$$
If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/81adf7f8-647c-479f-bd0f-8f896cd0c7c3/images/fe8c659b-613c-4fc0-a165-b07d10509323/1510a052325892668888784527ddbb81323a45d9.svg)

Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(3,-8)}$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^3$ and $g(x) = 5(x-2)^3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $g$ can be obtained from the graph of $f$ using two transformations.

- Give a full geometric description of each of the transformations. [2]


The graph of $g$ is translated by 4 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis, and 1 unit in the direction of the negative $y$-axis to give the graph of a
function $h$.
The point P$(1,1)$ on the graph of $f$ is translated to point Q on the
graph of $h$.

- Find the coordinates of Q.[4]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $5$}} \\[6pt]\text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis.}}\end{aligned}
$$

- If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ from part (a), and transformation $3$ from part (b) to P, we find

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1a61284-0cae-4301-9a9e-89a7e58d9d56/images/b28c508c-6131-4aee-a6fd-a87b131e9f21/577066d1f46b6880207621796d732b7e8ac43d46.svg)

Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(7,4)}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$.

- On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3]


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)


- Find the coordinates of:
- the $x$-intercept;
- the $y$-intercept. [2]



The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$.

- Find$g(x)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $y = f(x)$ for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)


- 
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(0.996,0)}$
- Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}y &= f(0) \\[6pt]&= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]&\approx -2.52\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,-2.52)}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]&= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]&\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Let $f(t) = 3t^2 + 27$, where $t > 0$.
The graph of a function $g$ is obtained when the graph of $f$ is
transformed by

$$
\begin{aligned}&\text{a stretch by a scale of\hspace{0.05em} $\dfrac{1}{9}$ \hspace{0.05em}parallel to the $y$-axis, followed by} \\&\text{a horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5}\\\end{aligned}
$$


- Find $g(t)$, giving your answer in the form $a(t - b)^2 + c$.
[4]


A particle moves along a straight line so that its velocity in
m s$^{-1}$, at time $t$ seconds, is given by
$g(t)$.

- Find the distance the particle travels between$t = 7$and$t = 10$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3em} g(t) &= \dfrac{1}{9}f(t - 4) - 5  \\[6pt]&= \dfrac{1}{9}\big[3(t - 4)^2 + 27\big] - 5 \\[6pt]&\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2}\end{aligned}
$$

- The distance the particle travels between $t = 7$ and $t = 10$ is
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{4.8em} \text{distance} &= \int_7^{10} \left|g(t)\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[2pt]&= \int_7^{10} \left|\dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[9pt]&\answer{= 15 \text{ m}}  \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=2\cos\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+3$ and $g(x)=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+2$.
The function $f$ is mapped onto $g$
by three transformations.

- Fully describe each of the transformations and the order in which they must be applied.[3]

A new function is such that $h(x)=g(x)+k$ where $k \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Find the minimum value of$k$such that$h(x) \geq 0$for all$x$.[2]
list.markScheme:
- By considering the differences between the functions we can work out the transformations needed to map $f(x)$ to $g(x)$.First we notice that the inner functions are different.
$$
\begin{align*}f(x)=2\cos\left(x\textcolor{blue}{\,-\,\frac{\pi}{2}}\right)+3\\[6pt]g(x)=4\cos\left(x\textcolor{blue}{\,+\,\frac{\pi}{2}}\right)+2\end{align*} 
$$
If we add $\pi$ units to the inner function of $f(x)$, it will equal the inner function of  $g(x)$.
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Hence
$$
\begin{align*}f(x+\pi)&=2\cos\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi\right)+3\\[6pt]f(x+\pi)&=2\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+3\end{align*}
$$
Comparing the function $f(x+\pi)$ to $g(x)$, we notice that the coefficient of cosine has been doubled.
$$
\begin{align*}f(x+\pi)=\textcolor{green}{2}\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+3\\[6pt]g(x)=\textcolor{green}{4}\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+2\end{align*} 
$$
Hence, if we multiply $f(x+\pi)$ by $2$ we would have
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}2f(x+\pi)=2(2\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+3)\\[6pt]2f(x+\pi)=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+6\end{align*} 
$$
If we continue comparing the function $2f(x+\pi)$ to $g(x)$, we see there is a difference of $4$ units.
$$
\begin{align*}2f(x+\pi)&=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\textcolor{red}{\,+\,6}\\[6pt]g(x)&=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\textcolor{red}{\,+\,2}\end{align*} 
$$
Hence, if we apply a vertical shift of $-4$ to $2f(x+\pi)$, we will obtain $g(x)$.
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}2f(x+\pi)-4&=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+6-4\\[6pt]&=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+2\\[6pt]&=g(x)\end{align*}
$$
Summarising the $3$ transformations, there isa horizontal shift $\textbf{left}$ of $\pi$ units, followed by a vertical stretch by a scale factor of $2$ , followed by a vertical shift of $-4$ units.Note: The horizontal shift could also come after the vertical transformations, however the two vertical transformations must be applied in the order given.
- In order to apply a vertical translation such that $g(x)>0$ for all $x$, we need to know the minimum value of $g(x)$.The minimum value of cosine is $-1$. Hence we can determine the minimum of $g(x)$
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{align*}    g(x)&=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+2\\[6pt]    &=4(-1)+2\\[6pt]    &=-2\end{align*}
$$
Hence, we need to translate the graph vertically upwards at least $2$ units.Therefore, the minimum value is $\answer{k=2}$.
$$
\begin{align*}     \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Consider the functions $f(x)=3\cos(x)+\dfrac{9}{2}$ and $g(x)=3\cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)+A$, where $x\in \mathbb{R}$ and $A< \dfrac{9}{2}$.

- Describe a sequence of two transformations that transforms the graph of$f$to the graph of$g$.[3]

The $y$-intercept of the graph $g$ is at the point $\left(0\,,\dfrac{9}{2}\right)$

- Find the range of$g$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- Applying a translation of $a$ units in the direction of the negative $x$-axis to a function $f$ is shown as $f(x+a)$, and a translation of $b$ units in the direction of the negative $y$-axis is shown as $f(x)-b$.Therefore a translation of $\dfrac{\pi}{3}$ units in the direction of the negative $x$-axis would be $f\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)$. We have
$$
\begin{align*}f\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg) &= 3\cos\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)+\dfrac{9}{2}\end{align*}
$$
Given that $A < \dfrac{9}{2}$, if we then apply a translation of $\dfrac{9}{2} - A$ units in the direction of the negative $y$-axis, we get
$$
\begin{align*}f\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg) - \bigg(\dfrac{9}{2} - A\bigg) &= 3\cos\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)+\dfrac{9}{2} - \bigg(\dfrac{9}{2} - A\bigg) \\[10pt]&= 3\cos\bigg(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg) + A \\[10pt]&= g(x)\end{align*}
$$
Therefore we have the following transformations in any order
$$
\begin{align*}T_1 &: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\text{translation of $\dfrac{\pi}{3}$ units in the direction of the negative $x$-axis}} \\[10pt]T_2 &: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\text{translation of $\dfrac{9}{2} - A$ units in the direction of the negative $y$-axis}}\end{align*}
$$

- We have $g(0)=\dfrac{9}{2}$. Solving for $A$, we get
$$
\begin{align*}3\cos\left(0+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)+A &= \dfrac{9}{2} \\[10pt]3\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right) + A & = \dfrac{9}{2} \\[10pt]A & = 3 \\[-12pt]\end{align*}
$$
Therefore $g(x)=3\cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)+3$ , and the following inequalities hold:
$$
\begin{align*}-1\leq \cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) &\leq 1 \\[10pt]-3\leq 3\cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) &\leq 3 \\[10pt]0\leq 3\cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)+3 &\leq 6 \\[10pt]0\leq g(x) &\leq 6 \\[-12pt]\end{align*}
$$
Therefore the range of $g$ is $\answer{0\leq g(x) \leq 6}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]
The function $f(x)=a\sin{(bx)}+c$ where $0 \leq x \leq \pi$ and $a,b,c \in \mathrm{R}$ is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/0547420d-b08d-4f9e-bd37-d903d3be790b/AA1154.JPEG)


The coordinates of the first two stationary points are $(\tfrac{\pi}{6}, -1)$ and $(\tfrac{\pi}{2},3)$ respectively.

- Find
- a.
- c.
- b. [5]



The domain of $f(x)$ is restricted to $\tfrac{\pi}{2}\leq x \leq k$, where $k \in \mathrm{R}$. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.

- Find the largest possible value of$k$.[2]

Another function is defined as $g(x)=-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3$.

- Determine the coordinates of thefirstmaximum value of$g(x)$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- 
- To find the value of $a$, which is known as the amplitude, we must find half of the vertical distance between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/a928181a-4fcd-4ea9-b71e-dc8f5cea02c9/AA1154a.JPEG)

We can see from the diagram that the curve is a reflection of $\sin{x}$ in the $x-$axis, therefore the value of $a$ must be negative.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    a&=-\frac{3-(-1)}{2}\\[6pt]    &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-2}  \tag*{\textbf{R1}}\end{align*}
$$

- To find the  value of $c$ we must find the $y-$value half way between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/f6143e17-9146-4ce4-9c33-b01bced64c56/AA1154b.JPEG)

Therefore
$$
\begin{align*}    c&=\frac{3+(-1)}{2}\\[6pt]    &=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{1}  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- To find $b$ we use the formula $T=\frac{2\pi}{b}$.We can use the diagram to find $T$ and see that $\frac{T}{2}$ is the $x-$distance between the maximum and minimum values.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/c7dc5b6a-813a-4ffb-bafd-b8fb49ff2f45/AA1154c%20(1).JPEG)

Hence
$$
\begin{align*}    \frac{T}{2}&=\left(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-\tfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\\[6pt]    T&=2\left(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-\tfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\\[6pt]    T&=\frac{2\pi}{3} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$
Using this value of $T$ and the formula stated above we can find $b$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \frac{2\pi}{3}&=\frac{2\pi}{b}\\[6pt]    b&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$


- For an inverse to exist the function must be one-to-one, this means it must pass the horizontal line test. We can see this is satisfied by the red part of $f(x)$  shown below
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/2b4f5cbc-7374-4bd7-a0b3-ee6657792bc7/AA1154inv.JPEG)

We can see that if we add one complete time period to $\tfrac{\pi}{6}$ we will get $k$, hence
$$
\begin{align*}	k&=\tfrac{\pi}{6}+\tfrac{2\pi}{3}\\[6pt]	&=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\tfrac{5\pi}{6}}  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\end{align*}
$$

- First we split the vertical and horizontal transformations.The inner function of $f$ is the horizontal transformations and everything else is vertical.
$$
\begin{align*}	&-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3\\[6pt]	&\text{Vertical}& \hspace{1em} & \text{Horizontal}\\[6pt]	&\times -2 & \hspace{1em} & \div 2\\[6pt]	&+3 & \hspace{1em} &\end{align*}
$$
Lets do the vertical transformations first. We don't need to transform the entire function. It is easier to identify a single point and transform that.Notice that we are multiplying by a negative number, that means $g$ will be a vertical reflection of $f$.Therefore the first maximum point of $g$ will be the image of the transformation of the first minimum point of $f$.
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\end{align*}
$$
Therefore we need to apply our transformations to the point $(\tfrac{\pi}{6},-1)$.We transform the $y$-coordinate by $\times -2$ and then $+3$, therefore the transformed $y$-coordinate is $-1\times-2+3=5$.We transform the $x$-coordinate by $\times\tfrac{1}{1/2}$.therefore the transformed $x$-coordinate is $\tfrac{\pi}{6}\times2=\tfrac{\pi}{3}$.Therefore $\answer{\text{the first maximum of }g(x)\text{ has coordinates }(\tfrac{\pi}{3}, 5).}$
$$
\begin{align*}    \textcolor{white}{hack} \tag*{\textbf{A1A1}}\end{align*}
$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- For the graph of$f$, find:
- the $y$-intercept;
- the $x$-intercepts. [4]



The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2+k$.

- Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- For the graph of $f$, write down:
- the coordinates of the vertex;
- the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 4 units in the direction of the positive $y$ axis.

- Find$g(x)$, giving your answer in the form$g(x) = px^2 + qx + r$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- 
- Evaluating $f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9$ for $x = 0$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{5em} f(0) &= 3(0)^2 + 12(0) + 9 \\[6pt]&= 9 \end{aligned}
$$
Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,9)}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1.5em} 3x^2 + 12x + 9 &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[7pt](x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\[7pt]x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em}-1 \\\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the
$x$-intercepts are
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(-3,0)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(-1,0)}$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 3x^2 + 12x + 9 \\[6pt]&= 3\big[x^2 + 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]&= 3\big[(x + 2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \\[6pt]&= 3(x + 2)^2 - 3 \\\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we find
$\answer{a = 3,\hspace{0.25em} h = -2}$
and  $\answer{k = -3}$
- 
- $\answer{(-2,-3)}$
- $\answer{x = -2}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{4em} g(x) &= -f(x)+4 \\[6pt]&= -(3x^2 + 12x + 9)+4 \\[6pt]&\answer{= -3x^2 - 12x - 5}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2x^2 + 4x + p$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$p \in \mathbb{Z}$.

- The equation $f(x) = 0$ has two equal roots.
- Write down the value of the discriminant of $f$.
- Show that $p = 2$. [3]


- For the graph of $f$, find:
- the equation of the axis of symmetry.
- the coordinates of the vertex; [4]


- Write down the solution to the equation $f(x) = 0$. [1]

- The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2 + k$.
Find
the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection
in the $x$-axis. Find the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of
$g$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
- $\answer{\triangle  = 0}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2em} \triangle  &= b^2 - 4ac \\[4pt]0 &= 4^2 - 4(2)(p) \hspace{0.5em} \\[5pt]0 &= 16 - 8p \\[5pt]16 &= 8p \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{p = 2} \hspace{2.9em}
$$


- 
- Using the axis of symmetry formula, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \hspace{1.4em} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{x = -1} \hspace{2.9em}
$$

- Evaluating $f(x)=2x^2 + 4x + 2$ for $x = -1$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.2em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) + 2 \\[8pt]&= 0\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$

- $\answer{x=-1}$
- Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3em} f(x) &= 2x^2 + 4x + 2 \\[6pt]&= 2\big[x^2 + 2x\big] + 2 \\[6pt]&= 2\big[(x+1)^2 - 1\big] + 2 \\[6pt]&= 2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we find
$\answer{a = 2,\hspace{0.25em} h = -1}$
and  $\answer{k = 0}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.2em}  g(x) &= -f(x) \\[6pt]&= -2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex of
the graph of $g$ are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2(x-1)^2-8$, for $x\in\mathbb{R}$.

- Show that $f(x) = 2x^2-4x-6$. [2]

- For the graph of $f$:
- write down the coordinates of the vertex;
- write down the $y$-intercept;
- find both $x$-intercepts. [7]


- Hence sketch the graph of $f$. [3]


Let $g(x) = 6x^2$, for $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
The graph of $f$ may be obtained from the graph of $g$ using the
following three transformations:

$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1em} & \bullet\text{ a compression of scale factor $a$ in the $y$-direction, followed by} \\& \bullet\text{ a horizontal translation of $h$ units, followed by} \\& \bullet\text{ a vertical translation of $k$ units.}\end{aligned}
$$


- Find the values of$a, h$and$k$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 2(x-1)^2-8 \\[6pt] &= 2(x^2-2x+1)-8 \\[6pt]&\answer{= 2x^2-4x-6}\end{aligned}
$$

- 
- $\answer{(1,-8)}$
- $\answer{\text{P}(0,-6)}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}2x^2-4x-6 &= 0 \\[6pt]x^2-2x-3 &= 0 \\[6pt]\hspace{0.8em} (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \\[6pt]x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}3\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the $x$-intercepts
are
$\answer{\text{A}(-1,0)}$
and
$\answer{\text{B}(3,0)}$

- If we sketch the graph of $f$, we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/defd40b3-8635-4c03-88d0-1ea05c7ccca1/images/42674bdd-229f-43b4-bb47-2584f965f100/8374016b8a888aa9fc9466667cfab6ca4babdde2.svg)


- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}f(x) &= ag(x-h)+k \\[6pt]2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= a\big[6(x-h)^2\big]+k \\[6pt]2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= 6a(x-h)^2+k \hspace{2.5em}\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we
find
$\answer{a = 1/3,\hspace{0.25em} h = 1}$
and  $\answer{k = -8}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $f(x) = 2x^2-8x+6$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

- Write down the value of $f(0)$. [1]

- Solve the equation $f(x) = 0$. [3]


The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = a(x-h)^2+k$.

- Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]

- For the graph of $f$, write down:
- the coordinates of the vertex;
- the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 1 unit to the right and 3 units up.

- Find$g(x)$, giving your answer in the form$g(x) = px^2+qx+r$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(0) = 6}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}2x^2-8x+6 &= 0 \\[6pt]x^2-4x+3 &= 0 \\[7pt](x-1)(x-3) &= 0 \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{6.8em} \answer{x = 1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
$$

- Using the method of completing of square, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{1em} f(x) &= 2x^2-8x+6 \\[6pt]&= 2\big[x^2-4x\big]+6 \\[6pt]&= 2\big[(x-2)^2-4\big]+6 \\[6pt]&= 2(x-2)^2-2\end{aligned}
$$
Hence we find
$\answer{a = 2,\hspace{0.25em}h=2}$
and  $\answer{k=-2}$
- 
- $\answer{(2,-2)}$
- $\answer{x = 2}$

- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{4.4em} g(x) &= -f(x-1)+3 \\[6pt]&= -\big[2((x-1)-2)^2-2\big]+3 \\[6pt]&= -2(x-3)^2+5 \\[6pt]&= -2(x^2-6x+9)+5 \\[6pt]&\answer{= -2x^2+12x-13}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x) = a(x+1)(x+5)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$a \in \mathbb{Z}$. The following diagram shows part of the graph of
$f$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5a0794f4-b904-4254-9ade-c72ff4d130c0/c560b93b90031104353dd8752d2c6976f60f1751.svg)


The graph of $f$ has $x$-intercepts at $(p,0)$ and $(q,0)$, and a
$y$-intercept at $(0,-10)$.

- 
- Write down the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
- Find the value of $a$. [6]


- Find the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]

- Find the coordinates of the vertex. [3]


The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection in the $y$-axis, followed by a translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis. The point P$(-2,6)$ on the graph of $f$ is mapped to point Q on the graph of
$g$.

- Find the coordinates of Q.[4]
list.markScheme:
- 
- $\answer{p = -5}$  and
$\answer{q = -1}$
- Using the coordinates of the $y$-intercept, we find
$$
\begin{aligned}f(0) &= -10 \hspace{5.5em} \\[6pt]a(0+1)(0+5) &= -10  \\[6pt]5a &= -10  \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\answer{a = -2}
$$


- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.8em} f(x) &= -2(x+1)(x+5) \\[6pt]&= -2(x^2+6x+5) \\[5pt]&= -2x^2-12x-10\end{aligned}
$$
Hence, using the axis of symmetry
formula, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{4.5em} x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]x &= -\dfrac{(-12)}{2(-2)} \\\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\hspace{2.2em} \answer{x = -3}
$$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{3.7em} f(x) &= -2x^2-12x-10 \\[6pt]&= -2\big[x^2+6x\big] - 10 \\[6pt]&= -2\big[(x+3)^2 - 9\big] - 10 \\[6pt]&= -2(x+3)^2 + 8\end{aligned}
$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are  $\answer{(-3,8)}$
- We have
$$
\begin{aligned}\hspace{2.9em} \text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{reflection in the $y$-axis} \\\text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{translation of two units upwards}\end{aligned}
$$
If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5463dadf-bc47-4d8c-a965-e2b73e47474d/e1df7f8211664f00389891c42cbdf0bb7d3cdd9a.svg)

Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,8)}$
